a machine readable transcription

Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive.

notesStmt.note: Edward Grier notes that the paper matches that of a manuscript dated 1855 or earlier, suggesting a similar date for this manuscript (Notebooks and Unpublished Prose Manuscripts [New York: New York University Press, 1984], 1:171).

revisionDesc.change: checked; revised repository information in header

body.ab: And to the soul every feeble and helpless creature is its child
body.p: Ministers Clergymen? get their two or ten thousand a year, and members of Congress their eight dollars a day; and certainly it is right enough as the by the moral theory that floats on the surface;.—wWhich is exactly the same as the paper money theory; every body knows that it is not money and the puzzle is never clearly exactly satisfied; but the bills pass and we will take them as long as we other folks do.—

Moon blind moon eyed horse.—There are some horses who see perfectly well except at a certain change or quartering of the moon.—At that period, no matter when it comes, they are blind.—Horses so affected are liable by any bad management hard work &c to become confirmedly blind
